construction: The schematic shows a two stage amplifier with RC coupling.  Each stage has one transistor in the common-emitter configuration.  Nodes for the input signal and the parameters have been given to you. Notice that the resistor are the same in both stages and have the same names.  Assume that the input signal frequency is such that the capacitors can be considered short circuits for the signal.  Construct a model of the AC behavior of the circuit, and plot the output voltage.  Is it in phase or out of phase with the input?
execution: The schematic shows a two stage amplifier with RC coupling.  Each stage has one transistor in the common-emitter configuration.  Notice that the resistor are the same in both stages and have the same names.  Assume that the input signal frequency is such that the capacitors can be considered short circuits for the signal.

Nodes for the input signal and the parameters have been given to you. Notice that the resistor are the same in both stages and have the same names.  Assume that the input signal frequency is such that the capacitors can be considered short circuits for the signal.  Construct a model of the AC behavior of the circuit, and plot the output voltage.  Is it in phase or out of phase with the input?

givenModelNodes.name: Max input V
givenModelNodes.description: Maximum voltage of input signal

givenModelNodes.name: Wavelength
givenModelNodes.description: Wavelength of the signal

givenModelNodes.name: Input v
givenModelNodes.description: AC input signal voltage

givenModelNodes.name: R of Rs
givenModelNodes.description: Resistance of the swamping resistor Rs

givenModelNodes.name: R of R1
givenModelNodes.description: Resistance of R1

givenModelNodes.name: R of R2
givenModelNodes.description: Resistance of R2

givenModelNodes.name: R of RC
givenModelNodes.description: Resistance of collector resistor RC

givenModelNodes.name: R of RE
givenModelNodes.description: Resistance of emitter resistor RE

givenModelNodes.name: R of RL
givenModelNodes.description: Resistance of load resistor RL

givenModelNodes.name: AC Ib into Q1
givenModelNodes.description: AC component of current into base of transistor Q1
givenModelNodes.explanation: The loop containing the input signal generator is comprised of the swamping resistor, Rs, the capacitor next to it, the emitter-based junction and the capacitor shorting the signal at the emitter to ground.  Thus, because the emitter-base junction is forward biased, it has a much smaller resistance then Rs, so the total resistance around the loop can be approximated by Rs.  Thus, one can use Ohm's law to get the AC current around this loop.

givenModelNodes.name: AC Ic into Q1
givenModelNodes.description: AC component of current into collector of Q1
givenModelNodes.explanation: Assuming transistor biased to be in its active region, this is just beta times base current.

givenModelNodes.name: AC V across Rc and R1
givenModelNodes.description: AC component of voltage drop across Rc and R1
givenModelNodes.explanation: Q1 is sucking an AC current from the supply via its collector and sending it via the emitter to ground.  This current must thus pass through the parallel combination of resistor Rc at Q1 and resistor R1 at Q2.  The capacitor between them acts like a short of the AC current.  Since one has the current into the collector, one can calculate the voltage drop across them using Ohm's law.

givenModelNodes.name: R of Rc and R1
givenModelNodes.description: Resistance of parallel resistors
givenModelNodes.explanation: For the AC signal, one can ignore the capacitor between RC at Q1 and R1 at Q2.  These two resistors thus form a parallel resistor sub-circuit.  There is a handy formula, which you should know, for calculating the resistance of the sub-circuit.

givenModelNodes.name: AC Vb of Q2
givenModelNodes.description: AC component of base voltage at Q2
givenModelNodes.explanation: The output voltage of stage one, which is the voltage at the collector of Q1, is connected to the input of stage two, which is the base of Q2, via a capacitor.  That's why this amp is called "RC coupled."   As long as the frequency of the signal is high enough, the coupling capacitor acts like a short. When the frequency is too low, then the capacitor's impedance resists it.

givenModelNodes.name: AC Ib into Q2
givenModelNodes.description: AC component of current into base of Q2
givenModelNodes.explanation: The AC voltage at the base of Q2 drives a current to ground via both R2 and the EB junction of Q2.  The emitter capacitor of Q2 can be considered a short.  Because the resistance of R2 is so much larger than the resistance of the EB junction, we can assume all the AC current flows through the EB junction, and use Ohm's law to calculate it.

givenModelNodes.name: R of EB junction
givenModelNodes.description: Resistance of EB junction of transistors
givenModelNodes.explanation: Although the forward-biased junctions are nearly shorts, they have some resistance.   The exact amount depends on the biasing, so let's just assume 100 ohms.

givenModelNodes.name: AC Ic into Q2
givenModelNodes.description: AC component of current into collector of Q2
givenModelNodes.explanation: As usual, assume Q2 is in active region, and multiply by beta.

givenModelNodes.name: AC V across Rc at Q2
givenModelNodes.description: AC component of voltage across Rc at Q2
givenModelNodes.explanation: The collector of Q2 pulls AC current into itself from Vcc via Rc.  Thus, one can use Ohm's law to calculate the voltage dropped by Rc.

givenModelNodes.name: AC Vc of Q1
givenModelNodes.description: AC component of voltage at collector of Q1
givenModelNodes.explanation: The voltage drop of Rc and R1 caused by the AC current into the collector is in phase with the input signal.  however, by Kirchhoff's voltage law, the voltage at the collector is the Vcc minus that drop.  This inverts the input signal.

givenModelNodes.name: AC output voltage
givenModelNodes.description: AC component of voltage at collector of Q2
givenModelNodes.explanation: The AC voltage drop across Rc is in phase with the AC voltage at the base of Q2.  By Kirchhoff's voltage law, the voltage at the collector is the Vcc minus that drop. Since the Vcc is constant, that makes the voltage at the collector 180 degrees out of phase from the input to Q2.

givenModelNodes.name: beta
givenModelNodes.description: Beta of both transistors

schemas.name: RC Coupled Multistage Amplifier AC Behavior
schemas.nodes: id20, id21, id22, id23, id24, id25, id28, id29, id32, id33
